deliberation: I checked 'House' (temple) and 'cloud filled the inner court' for figurative usage. I considered whether 'the glory of YHWH' is purely technical or also figurative. In this verse 'glory' (כְּבוֹד) is treated as a moving, space-filling entity and functions as an attribute-for-person metonymy for God’s manifest presence, with personification of 'glory' as an acting subject. The cloud and filling language otherwise read as literal within the vision.

deliberation: I examined 'take fire' and 'from among the cherubs within the wheelwork' for metaphor or idiom. Within the visionary world these are literal instructions; the text does not phrase them as a comparison (no כְּ) or as an idiom, though the action is symbolically significant. I therefore did not classify any explicit figurative expressions.

This verse continues the literal narrative of the vision: a cherub stretches out a hand to the fire and hands it to the linen-clothed figure. The language is straightforward action description without similes, metaphors, or metonymic shorthand beyond normal narrative usage.

The verse notes that the cherubs appeared to have the form of a human hand under their wings. 'Form of a human hand' (תַּבְנִית יַד־אָדָם) is descriptive of morphology in the vision, not an 'X is Y' or 'like Y' comparison. I did not identify independent figurative language here.

I checked especially the description of the wheels. The phrase 'their appearance was like the beryl stone' uses כְּ plus a noun, which is a standard visual simile. The rest of the verse is spatial description of number and position of wheels.

deliberation: This verse details the movement of the creatures and wheels, stressing that they do not turn as they move. The language is spatial and mechanical, without markers of simile, metaphor, or other figures like merism or hyperbole.

I considered whether 'full of eyes all around' is metaphorical for knowledge. In the vision’s own terms, however, Ezekiel simply reports that the bodies and wheels are literally covered with eyes; the text does not signal 'like eyes' or use 'eye' idiomatically here. The symbolic meaning is theological, but the wording itself is not cast as figurative.

The statement that these are 'the wheels' called 'the wheelwork' (הַגַּלְגַּל) is a naming, not a figure of speech. There is no comparison, personification, or idiomatic use that would qualify as figurative language in this line.

The verse lists the four faces (cherub, human, lion, eagle). Though the faces are symbolically loaded, the wording is simple identification ('the face of...', 'the second...', etc.) without 'like/as' or metaphorical predication. Thus I did not treat any phrase as figurative language in the technical sense requested.

This verse states that the cherubs ascended and identifies them with the 'living creature' previously seen. It is cross-referential, not figurative; 'living creature' (הַחַיָּה) is a label Ezekiel already uses for these beings, not a metaphor in this context.

The description relates the synchronized movement of cherubs and wheels. All expressions are literal within the visionary framework; no comparatives, idioms, or personifications of non-personal abstractions appear.

I considered 'for the spirit of the creature was in them' for potential metaphor. Within Ezekiel's vision this is an ontological claim about how the creatures and wheels are animated, not a figurative 'spirit of X' idiom. The rest is straightforward movement description, so I did not mark any figurative expression.

As in v.4, 'the glory of YHWH' is portrayed as moving and standing, functioning as an entity. This treats 'glory' as a metonym for God's manifested presence and personifies the abstract noun by assigning it spatial actions.
